div.p: Most revered father, I will be brief with you now, partly because I have written more extensively to Mr. Haller, and partly because Kobler is leaving today unexpectedly and is urging me. I ask you to read with favor what I have given to Mr. Affinem. The people of Sondrio have been freed from the tyranny of the Beccaria family; beyond that, nothing has been concluded that is of any significance. Once the assembly is completed, I will diligently write to you about the proceedings. Now I ask you to have mercy on us and kindly take up our cause.
There is much for me to do amidst the many traps set for me, in which I can barely take a step.
Most urgently from Chur. Both Mr. Consuls and Campell, my inseparable colleague, send their greetings to you. 1573, January 19, Chur.

Subscribed to your reverence, Th[obias] I[conius]. The church of Maienfeld sends 10 collected gold coins for the dispersed French; the rest from some others will be sent by Mr. Campell with letters until better times.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, chief minister of the church, etc., his most esteemed and eternally revered.
